title: Mega-Dose Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Mega-Dose oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is a multivitamin product used to treat or prevent vitamin deficiency due to poor diet, certain illnesses, or during pregnancy. [Vitamins](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/lifestyle-guide-11/vitamin-expert) are important building blocks of the body and help keep you in good health. How to use Mega-Dose Tablet Take this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth), usually once daily or as directed. Follow all directions on the product package, or take as directed by your doctor. Do not take more than the recommended dosage. If you have any questions, ask your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Take this medication regularly in order to get the most benefit from it. To help you remember, take it at the same time each day. Side Effects [Constipation](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-constipation), [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), or [upset stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting) may occur. These effects are usually temporary and may disappear as your body adjusts to this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx). If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. If your doctor has prescribed this medication, remember that your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Warnings If your brand of multivitamin contains iron, it is important to keep this product out of reach of children. Accidental [overdose](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/drug-overdose) of iron-containing products is a leading cause of fatal poisoning in children younger than 6 years. If overdose does occur, get medical help right away or call a poison control center. Precautions Before taking this product, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to any of its ingredients; or to soy/peanut found in some brands; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. Before taking this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical history, especially of: use/abuse of alcohol, [liver problems](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/liver-and-hepatic-diseases), [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach)/intestinal problems (such as If your brand of multivitamin also contains [folic acid](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8334/folic+acid+oral/details), be sure to tell your doctor or you have [vitamin B12 deficiency](https://www.webmd.com/diet/vitamin-b12-deficiency-symptoms-causes) ( [pernicious anemia](https://www.webmd.com/diet/vitamin-b12-deficiency-symptoms-causes)) before taking it. affect certain lab tests for [vitamin B12 deficiency](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/vitamin-b12-rm-quiz-html) without treating this [anemia](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-anemia-basics). Untreated [vitamin B12](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-926-vitamin+b12.aspx?activeingredientid=926&activeingredientname=vitamin+b12) deficiency may result in serious nerve problems (such as [peripheral neuropathy](https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-peripheral-neuropathy-basics)). Consult your doctor or pharmacist for details. Before having surgery, tell your doctor or [dentist](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/oral-health-care-providers) about all the products you use (including [prescription drugs](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), nonprescription drugs, and herbal products). Tell your doctor if you are pregnant before using this medication. This medication passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. If your brand of multivitamin also contains iron, avoid taking this product at the same time as antacids, bisphosphonates (for example, [alendronate](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-7174-ALENDRONATE+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=1257&drugname=Alendronate+Oral)), levodopa, [thyroid](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-thyroid) medications some [antibiotics](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/rm-quiz-antibiotics-myths-facts) (for example, tetracyclines, quinolones such as [ciprofloxacin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-7748/ciprofloxacin+oral/details)). Ask your doctor or pharmacist about how long you should wait between doses and for help finding a dosing schedule that will work with all your medications. If your brand of multivitamin also contains [folic acid](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8334/folic+acid+oral/details), be sure to tell your doctor or pharmacist if you take certain anti- [seizure](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics) drugs (including hydantoins such as phenytoin). This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) may interfere with certain lab tests, possibly causing false test results. Make sure lab personnel and all your doctors know you use this drug. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Symptoms of [overdose](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/drug-overdose) may include: [stomach pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/abdominal-pain-causes-treatments), [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea). Keep all medical and lab appointments. Some brands may also contain ingredients such as [docusate](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8646/docusate+calcium+oral/details). Ask your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you have questions about the ingredients in your brand. This product is not a substitute for a proper diet. Remember that it is best to get your [vitamins](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/lifestyle-guide-11/vitamin-expert) from healthy foods. Maintain a well- [balanced diet](https://www.webmd.com/diet/dieter-assessment/default.htm) and follow any dietary guidelines as directed by your doctor. If you are taking this product on a prescribed schedule and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. Take your next dose at the regular time. Do not double the dose to catch up. Store at room temperature away from light and moisture. Do not store in the bathroom. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
